title: Has anyone that ever thought about writing a book actually done so during this pandemic imposed break? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes! At the beginning of 2019, I liquidated my life in Mexico and began to travel. I bought a series of one-way tickets to so many places I’d always wanted to go…plus I had people to meet and my destiny awaited me …. So I began to write my second memoir, my first hit #1 LOVE The Beat Goes On, in three categories this month in Amazon. It wasn’t as easy to write as I expected. First of all, I began right before we were qurantined. (I’m currently in Istanbul). Then someone very close to me lost his father. I admit I was a wreck and all over the board even though I’d created an outline before the pandemic hit. The final result is beautiful. I now have 17 books on Amazon, but this one is precious to me and the people that are in my life that I met along my journey. In 2008 I was given 6 months to live! I’m definitely a ‘kitten’ with 8 lives left to live! If you would like to see what life is like when you choose to live out of a suitcase, my book is on pre-order with Amazon, and will be released Sept. 30 CAFE CONFIDENTIAL,Unfiltered and intimate. Thanks!! Stay safe and healthy everyone!

I ramble in this answer a little. I have not written a book, nor really worked on one during the pandemic but NaNoWriMo is coming and the pandemic will still be happening so I can -and you can - still answer yes to this question! Ironically, my workload has increased during CoVID so I have not had much of a break. I guess I have saved some time that I would have spent on social events - restaurants, gatherings and even concerts in the summer. My CoIVD pandemic experience has been unusual, I think. When the disease closed schools in Ontario, Canada, I weighed 96 kg. That was in March. In early August, I was 78 kg! I had run a half marathon, completed a 7km swim and done 300 push ups in a day. Oh, not all of those in one day, those were three different days! I have thought about writing. I read through a draft and looked at: problems and confusing writing -that might have made sense a few years ago when I was deep into the story,found gaps where I need to explain more,refreshed my memory of the characters,worked to complete the story and give it a good ending -it had ended roughly 80% of the way into the story.But I have not worked much on the story. In November of this year - of every year - National Novel Writing Month takes place and people try to write a story - 50,000 words of one at least - in the month. the link is at the top of this answer. I love it and have completed it -the 50,000 words - many times but not actually completed a book. Maybe this year.

Someone I know from the Spiritual community, who has her own song albums out, sat down and wrote a book during the pandemic while she actually had the virus. It’s due for release later in the year. Plenty of people are doing it. I have heard stories of authors having troubles writing during this crisis, but just as many where nothing has changed for them, or indeed, they’re writing faster now. It’s been a mixed blessing for everyone. Personally, I’m ahead of my normal schedule this year with 6 books out, and at least another 2 to come this year. But then, I am something of a Hermit Writer, and the only thing different for me, was the food delivery service not working for a month early on.

I thought about doing one on my 29 tears in prison, but decided no one would be interested. After all many other ex-cons have already done it , plus there several ex-cons on YouTube, so whats the point. Although one Youtuber said I should start my own channel. That’s just not me. If I did anything, it would be a book. Another reason that I haven't done a book is I do not want young people thinking its cool when it is not. If anything, I would want them to learn from my experience instead of praising it. I absolutely detest young people saying “You were in prison? Wow that is cool!” No it is not!

Yes. Sort of. I was outlining before the lock-down. I started the actual draft more or less the time I was laid off work. I have now finished, doing some touch-up edit (the third revision draft) and it is already formatted and prepped and ready for upload and it will be available for purchase probably next week. Except…! My workplace did a partial open and I’ve been back at work for about half of the novel. Got to the end of Part 2 of 4 before I returned to work. So now I’m working full time and dealing with the stress of constant masks and sanitizing and six foot intervals when even getting groceries is a chore. And outlining on the NEXT book.

I’ve got the first line: “As on the day Melas was born, the fields were the color of tanned deerskin on the day of his funeral.” So, yeah. The book’s all done but for the writing, revision, publishing, and distribution.

I don’t doubt it for a moment. I imagine plenty have gone even further and are making their keyboards clatter as we think an d speak. Some will be new writers, some will be professionals making good use of the time to plan and write. Makes sense, doesn’t it?
Yes. I’m working on two right now. One I started more than a year ago is about a pandemic. The other is about a woman who is disappeared (Latin American).

I was into the final book of my sci-fi trilogy when it all hit the fan and I thought it would take till about now to finish. But the peace and quiet of the lockdowns enabled great efficiency and the book was instead published in early August.
I’ve thought about it a lot but just can’t make myself do it. I don’t know why. I certainly have the time now.
I am not anyone. Why should the pandemic need to be an excuse ? And the break is not over yet !
Every professional writer I know has started and or finished a book, script or record album during this pandemic. Writers write, artists create.
